awd_titl_txt: Planning: EES-HSI Program: Expanding Diversity in STEM by Broadening Participation in CUREs through Multi-Institutional Experiential Learning Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI) Program, this planning proposal aims to identify strategies and funding opportunities directed to enhancing activities necessary to build STEM education capacity at 2-year HSIs, by creating cross-institutional Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) as an educational model for integrating undergraduate research into introductory non-major and major STEM community college courses that can be continued as Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs), and progress as undergraduate projects when students transfer to a 4-year university STEM major. CUREs are high impact practices embedded into the course curriculum that have been proposed as an inclusive strategy for increasing access to the educational benefits of research. While the impact of CUREs on student success parameters has been widely demonstrated in 4-year institutions, little is known of the benefits of CUREs in 2-year colleges, specifically those with significant percentages of underserved students, such as HSIs. Discussions will be focused on how cross-institutional CUREs can improve STEM educational outcomes at 2-year institutions, engage students in undergraduate research, and close the gap in STEM degree completion of underrepresented students. Planning session outcomes will be critical in advancing knowledge of the benefits and unique challenges involved in the design and implementation of cross-institutional CURE programs. They will also aid in the identification of core elements that contribute to cross-institutional collaborations for improved student learning outcomes and enhanced interest in STEM career pathways among underrepresented students.

Planning sessions aim to lay the foundation for understanding benefits, methodology, and viability of implementing multi-institutional CUREs. CUREs will be designed with the goal of creating cohorts of STEM students and taking them through an academic pathway that involves experiential learning, mentoring, immersion in the process of science and engineering design, and opportunities to advance and persist in STEM careers.  To address these topics and assess the feasibility of the proposed STEM cross-institutional CURE program, they will hold discussions that will build and expand upon their prior work with undergraduate research and CURE implementation at Phoenix College (PC), STEM mentoring programs at PC (Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement Program), and NSF funded Center for Bio-mediated and Bio-inspired Geotechnics and Center for Nanotechnology Enabled Water Treatment experience in managing and conducting REU programs. Planning sessions will build on NSF-funded MCCCD STEM-CURE Program (NSF EES 1832543) and recommendations from PC HSI Conference: Improving STEM Education at HSI Community Colleges by Introducing High Impact Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) (NSF HRD 2211811) and will increase knowledge and understanding of adapting CUREs for STEM students at 2-year HSIs. Results will be disseminated to governmental  agencies  and  higher  education  organizations  via  educational  research journals, presentations at regional and national conferences, and institutional social media outlets. Findings will inform funding priorities for high impact educational interventions in 2-year HSIs, and provide effective models for STEM student engagement and persistence. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Community colleges (CCs) have a dual mission; to prepare students for university transfer and for entering the workforce. According to a 2024 Community College Research Center at Columbia University nationwide study, only 33% of students enrolled in CCs transferred to four-year institutions (2015 cohort); of those, only 16% of CC students attained a bachelors degree in six years, with lower rates for low-income, male, older, Black, and Hispanic students (Velasco et al 2024).  Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) provide a larger population of students with the opportunity to engage in research, and represent a strategy for increasing STEM workforce readiness, which requires to be prepared for solving problems within the context of interdisciplinary collaborations.  Multidisciplinary undergraduate research experiences represent a strategy for engaging undergraduates with the concerns of their communities and the society at large and better prepare them for transitioning to the workforce.


With the defined goal of identifying strategies for increasing community college transfer student degree attainment, we gathered  CURE practitioners throughout the Maricopa County Community College District (MCCCD) from Mathematics, Geology, Chemistry, Computer Sciences, and Biology and researchers and education specialists at Arizona State University (ASU) engineering and bioscience research centers and engaged in a series of discussions to assess the feasibility of 1) designing and implementing cross- departmental and cross- institutional multidisciplinary CUREs (mCUREs) in community college STEM transfer courses that can be continued as summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs) and, when students transfer to a four-year institution, as undergraduate research projects; and 2) creating cohorts of STEM students and taking them through an academic pathway that involves experiential learning, mentoring, immersion in the process of science and engineering design, and opportunities to advance and persist in STEM careers.  Participants in the discussions:  1) designed and piloted the mCURE (Soil mCURE) (Table 1) as a model of instruction in community colleges that can be continued as a REU or undergraduate research project when students transfer to a four-year STEM program; 2)  established a STEM cross-disciplinary professional community of practice directed to engage and support programs that promote STEM student transfer and degree completion; 3) identified the most suitable NSF programs for funding the mCURE program implementation at Phoenix College (Figure 1); and 4) submitted two proposals (NSF # 2513387 and NSF # 2515221, currently under consideration) for disseminating and sustaining the use of mCUREs as an educational strategy to build institutional capacity directed to better prepare STEM transfer students for degree completion.


Broader Impacts


The broader impacts of the project include:


1)  Creating a cross-institutional and cross-discipline educational model for STEM transfer student success and degree completion.   Implementing mCUREs will create a model for establishing, maintaining, and expanding intramural and extramural collaborations among STEM faculty and students at community colleges, partners at four year institutions, research groups, local industry and communities (Figure 1).  mCUREs will act as a force multiplier in our efforts to increase awareness of STEM traditional and nascent disciplines, opportunities and careers and to increase recruitment, retention, and degree completion of underrepresented students in the STEM areas.   Through participation in mCUREs while students are completing transfer credits at Phoenix College and involvement in undergraduate research (mCUREs, REUs, internships) the program will provide community college students with an effective toolbox and pathway to success, degree completion, and fast integration into the job market

 

2) Promoting professional exchanges between educators at two-year and four-year institutions for the advancement of quality STEM education.  The mCURE program is a collaborative endeavor to establish multidisciplinary and cross-institutional collaborations among STEM disciplines for engaging and preparing community college STEM students for transfer, research intensive programs, and completion of STEM degrees.  The program will provide faculty and students with relevant, real-world, current hands-on experiences and practical skills, while being exposed to interdisciplinary solutions to problems that directly impact their communities, cities and resources, and being prepared to contribute to a fast growing need for a high technical workforce


3) Generating knowledge that informs best practices and provides a comprehensive plan for implementing mCUREs in STEM lower-division courses at two-year institutions.  MCCCD 10 college structure will enable us to replicate the mCURE model at multiple two-year HSIs. Identification of the unique barriers associated with the implementation of mCUREs will benefit faculty who teach lower-division courses at four-year institutions, ultimately fostering a shift in the  ways STEM courses are taught while providing an educational high impact practice for a more inclusive and diverse STEM pipeline


4) Building capacity at two-year HSI institutions.  mCUREs foster an array of collaborations (STEM professional communities of practice, research, collaborative programs, grants, consortiums) that enhance the research capabilities of community college faculty and students by promoting professional exchange of knowledge among two- year and four-year faculty and industry partners and awareness of innovative trends and solutions to problems that society affect society.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Anna Marti-Subirana

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1 shows the main components of the mCURE program. Students enrolled in mCUREs continue their research as summer Research Undergraduate Experiences (REUs) and later as undergraduate projects when they transfer

por.por_txt_cntn:
Community colleges (CCs) have a dual mission; to prepare students for university transfer and for entering the workforce. According to a 2024 Community College Research Center at Columbia University nationwide study, only 33% of students enrolled in CCs transferred to four-year institutions (2015 cohort); of those, only 16% of CC students attained a bachelors degree in six years, with lower rates for low-income, male, older, Black, and Hispanic students (Velasco et al 2024). Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) provide a larger population of students with the opportunity to engage in research, and represent a strategy for increasing STEM workforce readiness, which requires to be prepared for solving problems within the context of interdisciplinary collaborations. Multidisciplinary undergraduate research experiences represent a strategy for engaging undergraduates with the concerns of their communities and the society at large and better prepare them for transitioning to the workforce.


 
 


With the defined goal of identifying strategies for increasing community college transfer student degree attainment, we gathered CURE practitioners throughout the Maricopa County Community College District (MCCCD) from Mathematics, Geology, Chemistry, Computer Sciences, and Biology and researchers and education specialists at Arizona State University (ASU) engineering and bioscience research centers and engaged in a series of discussions to assess the feasibility of 1) designing and implementing cross- departmental and cross- institutional multidisciplinary CUREs (mCUREs) in community college STEM transfer courses that can be continued as summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs) and, when students transfer to a four-year institution, as undergraduate research projects; and 2) creating cohorts of STEM students and taking them through an academic pathway that involves experiential learning, mentoring, immersion in the process of science and engineering design, and opportunities to advance and persist in STEM careers. Participants in the discussions: 1) designed and piloted the mCURE (Soil mCURE) (Table 1) as a model of instruction in community colleges that can be continued as a REU or undergraduate research project when students transfer to a four-year STEM program; 2) established a STEM cross-disciplinary professional community of practice directed to engage and support programs that promote STEM student transfer and degree completion; 3) identified the most suitable NSF programs for funding the mCURE program implementation at Phoenix College (Figure 1); and 4) submitted two proposals (NSF # 2513387 and NSF # 2515221, currently under consideration) for disseminating and sustaining the use of mCUREs as an educational strategy to build institutional capacity directed to better prepare STEM transfer students for degree completion.


 
 


Broader Impacts


 
 


The broader impacts of the project include:


 
 


1) Creating a cross-institutional and cross-discipline educational model for STEM transfer student success and degree completion.  Implementing mCUREs will create a model for establishing, maintaining, and expanding intramural and extramural collaborations among STEM faculty and students at community colleges, partners at four year institutions, research groups, local industry and communities (Figure 1). mCUREs will act as a force multiplier in our efforts to increase awareness of STEM traditional and nascent disciplines, opportunities and careers and to increase recruitment, retention, and degree completion of underrepresented students in the STEM areas.  Through participation in mCUREs while students are completing transfer credits at Phoenix College and involvement in undergraduate research (mCUREs, REUs, internships) the program will provide community college students with an effective toolbox and pathway to success, degree completion, and fast integration into the job market








2) Promoting professional exchanges between educators at two-year and four-year institutions for the advancement of quality STEM education. The mCURE program is a collaborative endeavor to establish multidisciplinary and cross-institutional collaborations among STEM disciplines for engaging and preparing community college STEM students for transfer, research intensive programs, and completion of STEM degrees. The program will provide faculty and students with relevant, real-world, current hands-on experiences and practical skills, while being exposed to interdisciplinary solutions to problems that directly impact their communities, cities and resources, and being prepared to contribute to a fast growing need for a high technical workforce




3) Generating knowledge that informs best practices and provides a comprehensive plan for implementing mCUREs in STEM lower-division courses at two-year institutions. MCCCD 10 college structure will enable us to replicate the mCURE model at multiple two-year HSIs. Identification of the unique barriers associated with the implementation of mCUREs will benefit faculty who teach lower-division courses at four-year institutions, ultimately fostering a shift in the ways STEM courses are taught while providing an educational high impact practice for a more inclusive and diverse STEM pipeline

4) Building capacity at two-year HSI institutions. mCUREs foster an array of collaborations (STEM professional communities of practice, research, collaborative programs, grants, consortiums) that enhance the research capabilities of community college faculty and students by promoting professional exchange of knowledge among two- year and four-year faculty and industry partners and awareness of innovative trends and solutions to problems that society affect society.
